figure_1.title: Fig. 1
figure_1.caption: Fig. 1 Graph showing the accumulation in time of altmetrics data (sourced from Altmetric Explorer) relating to the discipline of parasitology

figure_2.title: Fig. 2
figure_2.caption: Fig. 2 Heatmap showing the covariation of altmetrics data from 44,377 publications from 2012 to 2019 with the five principal components, indexed from 0. Heatmap is based upon the PCA loadings data, which are derived from the eigenvalues and eigenvectors (providing magnitude and direction)

figure_3.title: Fig. 3
figure_3.caption: Fig. 3 Heatmap showing Spearmanʼs correlations amongst the social media types. Altmetric attention score (AAS) was included for convenience. The heatmap is annotated with the Spearmanʼs correlation coefficient

figure_4.title: Fig. 4
figure_4.caption: Fig. 4 Scatterplot showing the relationship between publication citations and the number of Mendeley readers (sourced from Altmetric Explorer) for the years 2012–2019. The vast majority of the papers are within the range 0–500 (Mendeley readers) and 0–400 (Citations). The trend line shown fits the equation Y ​= ​0.3834X + 0.0955 and the Spearmanʼs correlation coefficient is 0.78 with a P-value < 0.0001

figure_5.title: Fig. 5
figure_5.caption: Fig. 5 Word cloud of the top 50 nouns and noun phrases identified using GATE and TermRaider from 5,628 peer-reviewed publications receiving Twitter activity

claims.sentence:
Timeline for the uptake of social media
If we consider the timeline of the use of social media in parasitology, we can see a significant change in trends (Fig. 1).

Open in a new tab
Fig. 1 Graph showing the accumulation in time of altmetrics data (sourced from Altmetric Explorer) relating to the discipline of parasitology3.3.
Component 1 was moderately associated with AAS, News, Blog and Twitter mentions, whilst component 2 was strongly associated with Mendeley readers and citations (Fig. 2).

Open in a new tab
Fig. 2 Heatmap showing the covariation of altmetrics data from 44,377 publications from 2012 to 2019 with the five principal components, indexed from 0.
A heat map summarising the Spearmanʼs correlations is shown in Fig. 3.
The scatterplot resulting from a comparison of citations and Mendeley readers is shown in Fig. 4.

Open in a new tab
Fig. 3 Heatmap showing Spearmanʼs correlations amongst the social media types.

The heatmap is annotated with the Spearmanʼs correlation coefficient
Open in a new tab
Fig. 4 Scatterplot showing the relationship between publication citations and the number of Mendeley readers (sourced from Altmetric Explorer) for the years 2012–2019.
A word cloud summarising the top 50 noun phrases is shown in Fig. 5, which reinforces the nature of malaria research through terms such as malaria transmission and malaria elimination.

Analyses performed in GATE using ANNIE and the TermRaider plugin

Fig. 5 Word cloud of the top 50 nouns and noun phrases identified using GATE and TermRaider from 5,628 peer-reviewed publications receiving Twitter activity4.

Timeline for the uptake of social media
If we consider the timeline of the use of social media in parasitology, we can see a significant change in trends (Fig. 1).

Open in a new tab
Fig. 1 Graph showing the accumulation in time of altmetrics data (sourced from Altmetric Explorer) relating to the discipline of parasitology3.3.
Component 1 was moderately associated with AAS, News, Blog and Twitter mentions, whilst component 2 was strongly associated with Mendeley readers and citations (Fig. 2).

Open in a new tab
Fig. 2 Heatmap showing the covariation of altmetrics data from 44,377 publications from 2012 to 2019 with the five principal components, indexed from 0.
A heat map summarising the Spearmanʼs correlations is shown in Fig. 3.
The scatterplot resulting from a comparison of citations and Mendeley readers is shown in Fig. 4.

Open in a new tab
Fig. 3 Heatmap showing Spearmanʼs correlations amongst the social media types.

The heatmap is annotated with the Spearmanʼs correlation coefficient
Open in a new tab
Fig. 4 Scatterplot showing the relationship between publication citations and the number of Mendeley readers (sourced from Altmetric Explorer) for the years 2012–2019.
A word cloud summarising the top 50 noun phrases is shown in Fig. 5, which reinforces the nature of malaria research through terms such as malaria transmission and malaria elimination.

Analyses performed in GATE using ANNIE and the TermRaider plugin

Timeline for the uptake of social media
If we consider the timeline of the use of social media in parasitology, we can see a significant change in trends (Fig. 1).

Fig. 1 Graph showing the accumulation in time of altmetrics data (sourced from Altmetric Explorer) relating to the discipline of parasitology3.3.
Component 1 was moderately associated with AAS, News, Blog and Twitter mentions, whilst component 2 was strongly associated with Mendeley readers and citations (Fig. 2).

A heat map summarising the Spearmanʼs correlations is shown in Fig. 3.
